segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
segments.en: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu divāvihāragato pāpake akusale vitakke vitakketi, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: Now at that time that mendicant, during their day’s meditation, was thinking bad, unskillful thoughts, that is:

segments.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno anukampikā atthakāmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ saṃvejetukāmā yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: The deity haunting that forest had compassion for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:
make sure your thoughts are rational.
Thinking about the Teacher, the teaching,
the Saṅgha, and your own ethics,
and rapture and bliss as well, no doubt.
And when you’re full of joy,
you’ll make an end to suffering.”

segments.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu tāya devatāya saṃvejito saṃvegamāpādīti.
segments.en: Impelled by that deity, that mendicant was struck with a sense of urgency.

sections.title: At one time one of the mendicants was staying…

suttaplex.blurb: A mendicant plagued by bad thoughts is encouraged by a deity.
